abstract.text: Creates and returns a print operation for the document’s contents.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: The print settings dictionary to use.
The print operation can be run to print the document’s current contents. The
dictionary are added to a copy of the document’s print info, and the resulting print info is used for the operation.
You must override this method to enable printing in your app. The default implementation raises an exception.
In Swift, this method is marked with the
keyword to indicate that it throws an error in cases of failure.
When overriding this method, use the

abstract.text: Construct and manage a graphical, event-driven user interface for your macOS app.
An abstract class that defines the interface for macOS documents.
A print operation you can use to create a PDF representation of the document’s current contents.
Adds document-specific content to the Page Layout panel.
Prints the document’s contents, optionally displaying a print panel to the user.
The printing information associated with the document.
Creates and returns a print operation for the document’s contents.
Runs the modal page layout panel with the receiver’s printing information object.
Runs the specified print operation modally.
Exports a PDF representation of the document’s current contents.
Returns a Boolean value that indicates whether the document allows changes to the default printing information.
An object that stores information that’s used to generate printed output.
Constants that specify print job attributes.
An object that controls operations that generate Encapsulated PostScript (EPS) code, Portable Document Format (PDF) code, or print jobs.
Information about an error condition including a domain, a domain-specific error code, and application-specific information.
A singleton actor whose executor is equivalent to the main dispatch queue.

inlineContent.text: The print settings dictionary to use.
On return, if the print operation could not be created, a pointer to an error object that encapsulates the reason it could not be created.
